marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Author residing in New York, N.Y.
Note from Mary Mapes Dodge referring to a caricature of William E. Gladstone in PUNCH, and other subjects.

The diary and other papers, kept by William Donald between October 14, 1857 and June 9, 1859, describe a voyage to India via Egypt and Aden and sieges and engagements in the Sepoy Rebellion. Accounting notes, 1851-1865, on verso pages at end. Includes an illustrated newspaper article about Donald's military career as well as papers regarding his pension and discharge from the Royal Engineers. Also contains contract of indenture between an earlier William Donald and Robert William Duff, who agreed to train him in gardening.
Lawyer, judge, U.S. Representative of Maryland.
Letter to the governor of Maryland from Dorsey regarding the arming of state soldiers.

Letters to Dix from his brother, Roger Sherman Dix, describing the battle of Buena Vista. Letters written by John Adams Dix include an account of the activities of General Jacob Brown, commander of the Northern Division of the United States Army, 1820, and a letter from the period when Dix was secretary of state in New York.
Served as Secretary of the Navy (1853-1857).

Papers and letters including a power of attorney from John Moore Dobbin to John R. Buie to act in a slave sale; a legal comment on inheritance laws; letters from David Lowry Swain and Peter Force concerning the collection of documents on the history of North Carolina; and routine correspondence from Dobbin's term as Secretary of the Navy. Also included is one of the circulars that U. P. Levy, late captain of the U. S. Navy, sent to Dr. Joshua Cohen of Baltimore.
Personal letters to Sarah Ann Dogan from her husband, Joseph H. Dogan, and a friend.
Correspondence concerning the hiring of slaves, erecting irrigation machinery, shipping rice during the Civil War, and the evacuation of Charleston in 1865.
Related families residing chiefly in North Carolina.

Letters between members of the Dixon and Faircloth families of Greenville, Holliday Hill, and Kinston N.C. as well as other locations. Subjects include enslaved persons; the Civil War and disillusionment in the North after Bull Run; plans to build a house with slave labor; conversion to Christianity; revivals; and Dixon and Holliday family genealogy.
Gold miner in Sleepy Creek, S.C.
Letter (1855 Aug. 6) from Dorn to Joseph Slocum of New York concerning gold mining in S.C. Dorn describes problems in separating the gold after it is mined.

Civil War letters from Henry Kyd Douglas to Helen Macomb Boteler describing in detail military movements and camp life, including the battles of Cross Keys, 1862; Port Republic, 1862; and Fredericksburg, 1862, all in Virginia. Several of the letters were written from the Union military prison on Johnson's Island, near Sandusky, Ohio.
Letter to the Paymaster General of the United States Army from Dixon demanding a court of inquiry to investigate an accusation that had been brought against him.

Ulysses Doubleday was a U.S. Army officer, Colonel of the 3rd and 45th U.S. Colored Troops, and a member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was the son of Ulysses F. Doubleday, a congressman; and the brother of Abner Doubleday, a general in the Union Army who, at one time, was credited as the inventor of baseball, a claim that was later disputed.

Collection consists of a single 4 page letter from Doubleday to F. W. Ballard, an abolitionist. Doubleday expresses frustration that the army is in a state of confusion due to inadequate leadership, but that it is fortunate that President Lincoln has taken command of it. He note his reassurance at the President's increasing responsiveness to emancipationist influence.

Dorothea Dix was an activist for the indigent mentally ill. Her lobbying efforts resulted in the creation of several American mental asylums, including Dix Hill Asylum in Raleigh, N.C., later renamed Dorothea Dix Hospital. During the Civil War, Dix served as a Superintendent of Army Nurses.
Letters discuss Dix's advocacy work on behalf of the mentally ill and other routine matters.
Morgan Dix letter of introduction from Samuel F. B. Morse,
Morgan Dix was rector of Trinity Church in New York and the son of John Adams Dix.
Letter of introduction from Samuel F. B. Morse to Morgan Dix on behalf of Mrs. E. A. Cramer, whom Morse asks Dix to aid in her present troubles.
U.S. Congressman from Richmond County, N.C.; chairman, Committee on the Freedman's Bureau.
Routine correspondence related to Dockery's service as a United States congressman, including a letter, 1868, containing biographical information on Dockery.

A Douglass autograph and a letter from Douglass to Pinckney Benton Stewart Pinchback, 1875 July 16, mentioning a meeting to be held as a preliminary to the Republican National Convention of 1876. Douglass writes, "With the immense political power now in our hands, if wisely exercised, the colored people of this country need not fail to have all their rights respected nor fail to secure a respectable and proportionate representation both in the states and in the nation."
Orator, U.S. Representative, and later Senator from Iowa.
Correspondence referring to a contemplated commencement address at Trinity College, Durham, North Carolina, and Dolliver's cancellation of the engagement.
